what: Streamlining longitudinal microbiome profiling in Bioconductor
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Microbiome time-series data presents several distinct challenges, including complex covariate dependencies variety longitudinal study designs. Furthermore, several individual tools created aid longitudinal microbiome data analysis, -inclusive R-based toolkit remained elusive. address concerns, LegATo (Longitudinal mEtaGenomic Analysis TOolkit) risen ashes. LegATo suite open-source software tools longitudinal microbiome analysis extendable several different study forms, promising optimal ease--use researchers. toolkit allow researchers determine microbial taxa affected time perturbations onset disease lifestyle choices, predict effects perturbations time, including changes composition stability commensal bacteria. Currently, LegATo entertains number data cleaning, aggregation, modeling testing procedures. develop learn new methods, add toolkit accordingly. soon add hierarchical clustering tools multivariate generalized estimating equations (JGEEs) adjust compositional nature microbiome data.

what: Compatibility with MultiAssayExperiment and SummarizedExperiment objects
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: convenience LegATo part credited integration MultiAssayExperiment SummarizedExperiment objects. reliable clean data structures developed part MultiAssayExperiment SummarizedExperiment packages. MultiAssayExperiment container concisely stores SummarizedExperiment object, aggregates data matrices along annotation information, metadata, reduced dimensionality data (PCA, t-SNE, etc.). learn proper usage context objects, may want take look MultiAssayExperiment package vignette SummarizedExperiment package vignette. install two packages, run following code:
code: if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install("SummarizedExperiment")  if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install("SummarizedExperiment")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: order install development version LegATo Github, run following code: Now ’ll load LegATo package library:
code: if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly=TRUE))   install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("wejlab/LegATo") library(LegATo)

what: Formatting input data for use with LegATo
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: LegATo functions expect data properly formatted MultiAssayExperiment container compatible animalcules package. Obtaining properly formatted data can achieved easily via create_formatted_MAE() function LegATo package, detailed .

previous_headings: Formatting input data for use with LegATo
what: A note on compatibility with other packages
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: ’ve analyzed metagenomic 16S data via MetaScope package, can aggregate sample outputs user-input metadata using convert_animalcules() convert_animalcules_silva() functions. functions create taxonomy table collate data LegATo- animalcules-compatible MultiAssayExperiment object. can also format data analyzed elsewhere (like PathoScope 2.0) animalcules package upload step R Shiny app, select “Download Animalcules File” obtain MAE object can used LegATo.

previous_headings: Formatting input data for use with LegATo
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: purposes example, ’ll look example inputs unrelated main HIV-E infant data: Now ’ll look formatting : Counts Table Preview Taxonomy Table Preview Sample Table Preview note following: counts table composed raw microbial counts. one row taxon, one column sample. tax table composed taxonomy lineages. one row taxon, number columns taxonomic level (e.g., superkingdom, genus, species). lowest level taxonomy serves rownames table, also stored column. Taxonomic levels increase granularity left right. sample table contains entries sample, unique sample IDs rows. columns metadata samples, subjects units repeated measures taken, groupings, pairings, covariates. rownames(counts) == rownames(tax) colnames(counts) == colnames(sample)
code: counts <- system.file("extdata", "counts.csv", package = "LegATo") |>   read.csv(row.names = 1) |>   dplyr::rename_with(function(x) stringr::str_replace(x, "\\.", "-")) tax <- system.file("extdata", "tax.csv", package = "LegATo") |> read.csv(row.names = 1) sample <- system.file("extdata", "sample.csv", package = "LegATo") |> read.csv(row.names = 1) ndim <- 5 counts[seq_len(ndim), seq_len(ndim)] |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Counts Table Preview",                label = NA) tax[seq_len(ndim), ] |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Taxonomy Table Preview",                label = NA) sample[seq_len(ndim), ] |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Sample Table Preview",                label = NA)

previous_headings: Formatting input data for use with LegATo
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: data formatted correctly, can pretty easily use create_formatted_MAE() like :
code: output <- create_formatted_MAE(counts_dat = counts,                                tax_dat = tax,                                metadata_dat = sample)  class(output) ## [1] "MultiAssayExperiment" ## attr(,"package") ## [1] "MultiAssayExperiment" MultiAssayExperiment::assays(output) ## List of length 1 ## names(1): MicrobeGenetics SummarizedExperiment::assays(output[["MicrobeGenetics"]]) ## List of length 1 ## names(1): MGX

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: illustrate capabilities LegATo, turn published dataset following paper: Odom-Mabey AR, Gill CJ, Pieciak R et al. Characterization longitudinal nasopharyngeal microbiome patterns maternally HIV-exposed Zambian infants [version 1; peer review: 1 approved reservations]. Gates Open Res 2022, 6:143 (https://doi.org/10.12688/gatesopenres.14041.1) raw dataset archived Zenodo: Zenodo: Underlying data ‘Characterization longitudinal nasopharyngeal microbiome patterns maternally HIV-exposed Zambian infants’. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.725531324 details dataset altered inclusion package provided .

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: example data consists 167 NP swabs healthy HIV-exposed, uninfected (HEU; n=10) infants HIV(+) mothers HIV-unexposed, uninfected (HUU; n=10) infants HIV(-) mothers. total 7 samples collected per infant, missingness data. swabs identified sample library collected Lusaka, Zambia 2015 2016. analysis objective parse association NP resident bacteria infant HIV exposure first 3.5 months (14 weeks) life, critical time microbiome maturation. data processed PathoScope 2.0, sample outputs aggregated animalcules R package. analysis, work infant data subset data accordingly. leaves us 129 samples analysis.
code: dat <- system.file("extdata", "MAE.RDS", package = "LegATo") |>   readRDS()  dat_subsetted <- MultiAssayExperiment::subsetByColData(dat,                                                        dat$MothChild == "Infant")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: LegATo several functions manipulating MAE objects, delineated :

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: data aggregated via animalcules package, done example data, samples aggregated strain taxonomic level residual taxonomy IDs present. clean_animalcules_MAE() function cleans data suffering issues.
code: dat_cleaned <- clean_animalcules_MAE(dat_subsetted) ## Registered S3 method overwritten by 'httr': ##   method         from   ##   print.response rmutil

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Many metagenomic pipelines identify taxon abundances extremely small levels, can noisy deal analysis. filter_animalcules_MAE function smoothly transforms reads belonging taxa overall genera threshold filter_prop (filter proportion) argument, set 0.005.
code: dat_filt <- filter_animalcules_MAE(dat_cleaned, 0.005)

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: want take closer look data, can easily extract counts, taxonomy, sample metadata tables using parse_MAE_SE() function. Counts Table Sample Metadata Taxonomy Table
code: parsed <- parse_MAE_SE(dat_filt, which_assay = "MicrobeGenetics", type = "MAE")  parsed$counts[seq_len(5), seq_len(5)] |>    knitr::kable(caption = "Counts Table") parsed$sam[seq_len(5), ]  |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Sample Metadata") parsed$tax[seq_len(5), ] |>    knitr::kable(caption = "Taxonomy Table")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: fairly convenient summarize average number reads report get_summary_table(). table groups user-provided discrete covariates. Summary Table get_top_taxa function outputs data.frame lists taxa order relative abundance. Table genera, ranked abundance
code: group_vars <- c("HIVStatus", "MothChild") get_summary_table(dat_filt, group_vars) |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Summary Table", label = NA) best_genus <- get_top_taxa(dat_filt, "genus") best_genus |> knitr::kable(caption = "Table of genera, ranked by abundance")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: several plots can visualize changes relative abundance time, accounting given covariate. case, interested HIV exposure.
code: this_palette <- paletteer::palettes_d$ggsci$springfield_simpsons |>   magrittr::extract(seq_len(nrow(best_genus)))

previous_headings: Initial data exploration > Other data manipulation functions
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Alluvial diagrams illustrate individual taxa stream fields change position different time points. height stream field represents relative abundance taxon. given time point, stream fields ranked highest lowest abundance (top bottom). can constructed plot_alluvial().
code: plot_alluvial(dat = dat_filt,                taxon_level = "genus",                covariate_1 = "HIVStatus",               covariate_time = "timepoint",               palette_input = this_palette,               subtitle = "Alluvial plot")

text: can create spaghetti volatility plots elucidate changes time sample level given taxon. advantageous visualization methods often aggregates multiple samples lack granularity. plots can created plot_spaghetti().

text: Stacked bar plots used visualize relative abundance microbes given taxonomic level sample, represented single bar, labeled time point, plotted within HIV exposure status group separate mothers infant comparisons. Use plot_stacked_bar.
code: plot_stacked_bar(dat_filt, "genus",               "HIVStatus",              "timepoint",              palette_input = this_palette)

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: concrete analysis longitudinal microbiome data, LegATo provides NMIT, paired unpaired multivariate Hotelling’s T-squared test, generalized estimating equations (GEEs) linear mixed effects models (LMEMs/LMMs). Detailed explanations available LegATo website: * (NMIT)[] * Hotelling’s T-Squared Test * Modeling GEEs LMMs Otherwise brief overview method provided .

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: NMIT multivariate distance-based test intended evaluate association key phenotypic variables microbial interdependence. test determines longitudinal sample similarity function temporal microbial composition. authors thank Yilong Zhang providing code adaptation LegATo. Citations: Yilong Zhang, Sung Won Han, Laura M Cox, Huilin Li. multivariate distance-based analytic framework microbial interdependence association test longitudinal study. Genetic epidemiology, 41(8):769–778, 2017. doi:10.1002/gepi.22065.
code: dat_0.1 <- filter_animalcules_MAE(dat_cleaned, 0.1) NMIT(dat_0.1, unit_var = "Subject", fixed_cov = "HIVStatus",      covariate_time = "timepoint",      method = "kendall", dist_type = "F",      heatmap = TRUE, classify = FALSE, fill_na = 0)

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Hotelling’s T2 tests can used determine whether microbiome profiles exhibit notable differences trends across time groups. may use t-tests identify genera contributed differences. example, HEU HUU infants designated two sampling units relative abundances p abundant genera measured. paired tests, chose p = 6 variables ensure n < p singularity avoided T2 properly computed, n number measurements sampling unit. Normality met using microbe abundances log CPM units, calculated within function. Group comparisons can also tested unpaired data:
code: test_hotelling_t2(dat = dat_filt,                   test_index = which(dat_filt$MothChild == "Infant" &                                        dat_filt$timepoint == 6),                   taxon_level = "genus",                   # To avoid n < p, use top 5-6 species                   num_taxa = 6,                   paired = TRUE,                   grouping_var = "HIVStatus",                   pairing_var = "pairing") ## $df1 ## [1] 6 ##  ## $df2 ## [1] 2 ##  ## $crit_F ## [1] 19.32953 ##  ## $F_stat ## [1] 2.630189 ##  ## $pvalue ## [1] 0.3009049 test_hotelling_t2(dat = dat_filt,                   test_index = which(dat_filt$timepoint == 0),                   taxon_level = "genus",                   # To avoid n < p, use top 5-6 species                   num_taxa = 6,                   grouping_var = "HIVStatus",                   unit_var = "Subject",                   paired = FALSE) ## $df1 ## [1] 6 ##  ## $df2 ## [1] 13 ##  ## $crit_F ## [1] 2.915269 ##  ## $F_stat ## [1] 0.8992814 ##  ## $pvalue ## [1] 0.523911

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Generalized estimating equations (GEEs) described Liang Zeger (1986) extended Agresti (2002) widely used modeling longitudinal data, recently longitudinal microbiome data. genus present microbial aggregate samples, model normalized log CPM relative taxon counts, estimating effects time point HIV exposure status interaction, accounting underlying structure clusters formed individual subjects. GEE Outputs can also create plots covariates, saved folder specified user:
code: output <- run_gee_model(dat_filt, unit_var = "Subject",                         fixed_cov = c("HIVStatus", "timepoint"),                         corstr = "ar1",                         plot_out = FALSE,                         plotsave_loc = ".",                         plot_terms = NULL)  head(output) |> knitr::kable(caption = "GEE Outputs") tempfolder <- tempfile() dir.create(tempfolder)  # Trying out plotting output <- run_gee_model(dat_filt, unit_var = "Subject",               taxon_level = "genus",               fixed_cov = c("HIVStatus", "timepoint"),               corstr = "ar1",               plot_out = TRUE,               plotsave_loc = tempfolder,               plot_terms = "timepoint",               width = 6, height = 4, units = "in", scale = 0.7)  unlink(tempfolder, recursive = TRUE)

title: LegATo: Longitudinal mEtaGenomic Analysis Toolkit
text: LegATo suite open-source software tools longitudinal microbiome analysis. extendable several different study forms optimal ease--use researchers. Microbiome time-series data presents distinct challenges including complex covariate dependencies variety longitudinal study designs. toolkit allow researchers determine microbial taxa affected time perturbations onset disease lifestyle choices, predict effects perturbations time, including changes composition stability commensal bacteria. LegATo integrates visualization, modeling testing procedures. currently development, soon supplemented hierarchical clustering tools multivariate generalized estimating equations (JGEEs) adjust compositional nature microbiome data.

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
text: package performs multivariate distance-based test group comparisons microbial temporal interdependence. NMIT test provides comprehensive way evaluate association key phenotypic variables microbial interdependence. function recommended use filtering step using filter_animalcules_MAE.

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
code: NMIT(   dat,   unit_var,   fixed_cov,   covariate_time,   method = "kendall",   dist_type = "F",   heatmap = TRUE,   classify = FALSE,   fill_na = 0 )

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. unit_var numeric vector subject. fixed_cov character vector covariates interest found dat. covariate_time Character string giving name discrete time-based covariate metadata group abundances . method option correlation method ("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"). default method "kendall". dist_type character strin specifying type matrix norm computed. default "F". "M" "m"specifies maximum modulus elements x. "O", "o" "1"specifies one norm, (maximum absolute column sum); "" ""specifies infinity norm (maximum absolute row sum); "F" "f"specifies Frobenius norm (Euclidean norm x treated vector); heatmap logical value indicating whether draw heatmap. default TRUE. classify logical value indicating whether draw classifier tree. default FALSE. fill_na number 0 1 fill NA values. default value 0.

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
text: function returns analysis variance (ANOVA) table showing sources variation, degrees freedom, sequential sums squares, mean squares, F statistics, partial R-squared P values, based 999 permutations.

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
text: Yilong Zhang, Huilin Li, Aubrey Odom

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
code: dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |> readRDS() NMIT(dat, unit_var = "Subject", fixed_cov = "Group", covariate_time = "Month")

what: Clean up taxon names in a MultiAssayExperiment — clean_animalcules_MAE
title: Clean up taxon names in a MultiAssayExperiment — clean_animalcules_MAE
text: functional optional method fixing taxon names MultiAssayExperiment run filter_animalcules_MAE. Specifically removes brackets species names, replaces species labeled "others" "sp." finally replaces underscores spaces.

title: Clean up taxon names in a MultiAssayExperiment — clean_animalcules_MAE
code: clean_animalcules_MAE(dat)

title: Clean up taxon names in a MultiAssayExperiment — clean_animalcules_MAE
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output.

title: Clean up taxon names in a MultiAssayExperiment — clean_animalcules_MAE
text: animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment object   cleaned-taxonomy nomenclature.

title: Clean up taxon names in a MultiAssayExperiment — clean_animalcules_MAE
code: in_dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |> readRDS() clean_animalcules_MAE(in_dat) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'rmutil': #>   method         from #>   print.response httr #> A MultiAssayExperiment object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] MicrobeGenetics: SummarizedExperiment with 100 rows and 50 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files

what: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
text: function takes counts_dat, tax_dat, metadata_dat input creates specifically-formatted MAE object compatible use LegATo animalcules. Checks performed inputs ensure can integrated properly.

title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
code: create_formatted_MAE(counts_dat, tax_dat, metadata_dat)

title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
text: counts_dat matrix, data.table, data.frame consisting microbial raw counts data. colnames sample names rownames order tax_dat entries. tax_dat matrix, data.table, data.frame hierarchical taxonomic data. columns "family", "genus", "species" row uniquely delineating different taxon. rows order rows counts_dat. metadata_dat metadata table rownames equivalent samples colnames counts_dat.

title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
text: MultiAssayExperiment object.

title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
code: nsample <- ntaxa <- 3 counts_dat <- data.frame("X123" = runif(ntaxa, 0, 500),                          "X456" = runif(ntaxa, 0, 500),                          "X789" = runif(ntaxa, 0, 500)) tax_dat <- data.frame("class" = c("rand1", "rand2", "rand3"),                       "species" = c("rand4", "rand5", "rand6")) |>   as.data.frame() # Set rownames as lowest unique taxonomic level rownames(tax_dat) <- tax_dat$species metadata <- data.frame(Sample = c("X123", "X456", "X789"),                        Group = c("A", "B", "A"),                        Var = rnorm(nsample)) rownames(metadata) <- metadata$Sample out_MAE <- create_formatted_MAE(counts_dat, tax_dat, metadata) out_MAE #> A MultiAssayExperiment object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] MicrobeGenetics: SummarizedExperiment with 3 rows and 3 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files

what: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data
title: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data
text: function takes MultiAssayExperiment object specified taxon level interest creates long data.frame can used easily plotting counts data.

title: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data
code: get_long_data(dat, taxon_level, log = FALSE, counts_to_CPM = FALSE)

title: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. taxon_level Character string indicating level taxonomy aggregate counts data. Must name column MultiAssayExperiment::rowData(dat). log logical. Indicate whether assay returned log whichever assay specified "output_name". counts_to_CPM = TRUE well, log CPM assay also created. Default FALSE. counts_to_CPM logical. argument applies input_type counts assay. TRUE, output assays include normalized CPM assay. log = TRUE well, log CPM assay also created. Default TRUE.

title: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data
text: data.frame consisting counts data, taxa,   metadata.

title: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data
code: in_dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |> readRDS() out <- get_long_data(in_dat, "genus", log = TRUE, counts_to_CPM = TRUE) head(out) #>           taxon Sample Subject    Sex Month Group Pairing HairLength  Age #> 1 Acinetobacter    X-1      S1   Male     1     A       1   48.62753 21.9 #> 2 Acinetobacter    X-2      S2   Male     1     B       1   53.53195 67.7 #> 3 Acinetobacter    X-3      S3 Female     1     A       2   47.61090 78.9 #> 4 Acinetobacter    X-4      S4 Female     1     B       2   49.72870 48.6 #> 5 Acinetobacter    X-5      S5 Female     1     A       3   59.04509 48.4 #> 6 Acinetobacter    X-6      S6 Female     1     B       3   27.82404 29.6 #>   Sample_id Abundance #> 1       X-1      4518 #> 2       X-2     20029 #> 3       X-3    150813 #> 4       X-4       920 #> 5       X-5      1185 #> 6       X-6      2311

what:
Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome
data — run_gee_model
title:
Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome
data — run_gee_model
text: function takes animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment runs independent GEE model taxon. model predicts taxon log CPM abundance product fixed-effects covariates conditional grouping ID variable, usually unit repeated measurements taken. modeling approach works best small datasets multiple samples across many (>40) clusters/units.

title:
Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome
data — run_gee_model
code: run_gee_model(   dat,   taxon_level = "genus",   unit_var,   fixed_cov,   corstr = "ar1",   p_adj_method = "fdr",   plot_out = FALSE,   plotsave_loc = ".",   plot_terms = NULL,   ... )

title:
Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome
data — run_gee_model
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. taxon_level Character string, default "genus". unit_var Character string giving variable containing identifiers unit multiple measurements conducted, e.g. subjects. Default NULL; must supplied paired = FALSE. fixed_cov character vector naming covariates tested. corstr character string specifying correlation structure. following permitted: '"independence"', '"exchangeable"', '"ar1"', '"unstructured"'. p_adj_method character string specifying correction method. Can abbreviated. See details. Default "fdr". plot_out Logical indicating whether plots output alongside model results. Default FALSE. plotsave_loc character string giving folder path save plot outputs. defaults current working directory. plot_terms Character vector. terms examined plot output? Can overlap fixed_cov inputs. ... arguments passed ggsave plot creation.

title:
Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome
data — run_gee_model
text: data.frame modeling results.

title:
Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome
data — run_gee_model
text: P-values adjusted model coefficients within taxon. following methods permitted: c("holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "", "fdr", "none")

title:
Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome
data — run_gee_model
code: in_dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |>               readRDS() out <- run_gee_model(in_dat, taxon_level = "genus", unit_var = "Subject",                      fixed_cov = c("HairLength", "Age", "Group", "Sex"),                      corstr = "ar1") head(out) #>   Coefficient Coefficient Estimate Standard Error  Statistic Unadj p-value #> 1 (Intercept)            4704.2733     9242.28654  0.2590754   0.610756059 #> 2 (Intercept)           27036.2185    13974.99000  3.7427333   0.053037617 #> 3 (Intercept)            1139.1468      393.29821  8.3891008   0.003774776 #> 4 (Intercept)             271.1042       84.54737 10.2818739   0.001343434 #> 5 (Intercept)             210.2923       72.45671  8.4234430   0.003704137 #> 6 (Intercept)             893.8138      386.92571  5.3362838   0.020885952 #>   Lower 95% CI Upper 95% CI              Taxon Adj p-value #> 1 -13410.27548   22818.8220      Acinetobacter  0.63983968 #> 2   -354.25853   54426.6956    Corynebacterium  0.09723563 #> 3    368.29643    1909.9971     Staphylococcus  0.02768169 #> 4    105.39440     436.8140 Noviherbaspirillum  0.02768169 #> 5     68.27979     352.3049            Kocuria  0.02768169 #> 6    135.45333    1652.1742        Pseudomonas  0.04594909

what: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
text: function takes animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment object runs multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test. test expects comparison two distinct groups, compares abundances top microbes given taxon level groups. function allows paired unpaired tests. test null hypothesis population mean vectors equal, alternative unequal.

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
code: test_hotelling_t2(   dat,   test_index = NULL,   taxon_level = "genus",   num_taxa,   grouping_var,   paired = FALSE,   pairing_var = NULL,   unit_var = NULL,   save_table_loc = "." )

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. test_index argument used subsetting input dat, can character, logical, integer, list List vector. Default NULL. taxon_level Character string, default "genus". num_taxa number abundant taxa test. Needs small enough avoid n > p issues n smallest number samples units given group, p number microbes tested. grouping_var Character string, name DICHOTOMOUS grouping variable metadata dat. paired Logical indicating whether paired test conducted. Default FALSE unpaired test. pairing_var Character string giving variable containing pairing information. variable integer form. Must supplied paired = TRUE, otherwise default NULL. unit_var Character string giving variable containing identifiers unit multiple measurements conducted, e.g. subjects. Default NULL; must supplied paired = FALSE. save_table_loc character string giving folder path save t.test results. Note conducted Hotelling's T-test value <0.05.  Defaults current working directory.

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
text: list elements "df1", "df2", "crit_F", "F_stat" "pvalue" giving results test.

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
text: Hotelling's t-squared statistic (t2) generalization Student's t-statistic used multivariate hypothesis testing test means different populations. Note entries pairs missing values excluded. Referenced articles implementation tests: https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat505/lesson/7/7.1/7.1.14 https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat505/lesson/7/7.1/7.1.15 https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat505/lesson/7/7.1/7.1.4 https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat505/lesson/7/7.1/7.1.9

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
code: dat <- system.file("extdata", "MAE.RDS", package = "LegATo") |> readRDS() dat_0.05 <- filter_animalcules_MAE(dat, 0.05) out1 <- test_hotelling_t2(dat = dat_0.05,                   test_index = which(dat_0.05$MothChild == "Infant" &                                        dat_0.05$timepoint == 6),                   taxon_level = "genus",                   # To avoid n < p, use top 5-6 species                   num_taxa = 6,                   paired = TRUE,                   grouping_var = "HIVStatus",                   pairing_var = "pairing") out1                   #> $df1 #> [1] 6 #>  #> $df2 #> [1] 2 #>  #> $crit_F #> [1] 19.32953 #>  #> $F_stat #> [1] 2.693918 #>  #> $pvalue #> [1] 0.2952945 #>   out <- test_hotelling_t2(dat = dat_0.05,                   test_index = which(dat_0.05$MothChild == "Mother" &                                        dat_0.05$timepoint == 0),                   taxon_level = "genus",                   # To avoid n < p, use top 5-6 species                   num_taxa = 12,                   grouping_var = "HIVStatus",                   unit_var = "Subject",                   paired = FALSE) out                   #> $df1 #> [1] 7 #>  #> $df2 #> [1] 12 #>  #> $crit_F #> [1] 2.913358 #>  #> $F_stat #> [1] 0.5360667 #>  #> $pvalue #> [1] 0.7918588 #>
